column4: grrrrr.... apt-get keeps saying that the package is not installed when I try to rmove it, aptitude gives no output, and dpkg still lists it.  I can't reinstall it
because when I do it tries to "reconfigure" a non-installed package.  Is there some way to make it wiseup?

is there anyway to fix a messed up package database?  if so how?  exim4 won't reinstall because it errantly believes it is still installed.  The packages list in dpkg, but apt-get deson't think they are there and aptitude is useless.
do i have to reinstall because of a botched install of exim4?
how can I force aptitude to not try to reconfigure (but rather reinstall) a package it half way belives is there?
first things first, try a "sudo dpkg -P exim4"
copy your config files first if you need them
that should completely vape exim from your system
I get "Ignoring request to remove exim4 which isn't installed"
yet when I go to install it, it fails.  and they still list in when I do a dpkg -l
ok, you could try "sudo dpkg -i /var/cache/apt/archives/exim-blahblah.deb"
that should reinstall the package
fails, reports errors about a missing /etc/exim4 directory
could you paste the errors to a pastebin?
did you manage to paste the errors to a pastebin?
yes.  http://pastebin.com/718597
and then cygwin flipped out and killed everything :-P
hmm, try "touch /etc/exim4/exim4.conf" and then another reinstall command
that kinda did it.  How can I force it to redo everything from scratch, right up to its config dialog and original config files?
you could remove all the packages and re-install them, or you can re-run the configure bits with "sudo dpkg-reconfigure exim4-config"
seems to be working now, but we'll see.
